												Hours Logged - 44Okay so I promised myself that'd write an honest review of this game, but only after logging a fair few number hours in order to sure what I was writing is accurate.The game is a vast improvement on the 2014, more polished, more complicated (Love stripping an engine to find a mystery fault), and a lot more room for potential.I've logged 44 hours for this game and I'm not even bored, in fact I'm actually finding myself getting more enthralled due to the auction system, and the refurb jobs I currently have in the parking garage.So in summary:Pros:-- The game will always keep you guessing, even after you have got all the add on's for the garage.- The auction is brilliant, nothing more satisfying than buying a wreck and doing it up.- The cars you work on well rendered and have actual real world issues.- The test track is worth its weight in gold.Cons:-- The game needs more depth in regards to cars available.- I've got an over abundance of XP points and nothing to spend them on.- More DLC as the Youngtimer pack introduced what seems to be a Fiat 500.- The garage itself needs to be open to change, maybe allowing us to move stuff around.So in conclusion, this game is good but needs a little more refinement to make it great.4 out of 5JB

												I find it hypnotic and keep coming back for more.  Very well done.- Many car types included, especially if you purchase the (low cost) DLC- Paced as fast or slow as you want, never rushed- I prefer this to most sims; having no trace of tedium/grind found in most other sims- It's mostly a puzzle game for mechanical engineers.  Although even as a newbie to cars, the game helps you a lot, and in the meantime you'll learn a lot about how cars work- There is test driving of vehicles but no "racing" or multiplayer- The most fun is purchasing vehicles at auctions (fixer-uppers) and restoring them for profitable resale.  Take the extra used parts you gathered from these vehicles and repair customer old beaters for almost no cost to you (also very profitable)There is some degree of financial management / budgeting aspect in the game but it's minor.  Given the pacing and profitability of jobs coming in, I have never needed any financial help, and only noticed after playing for 80+ hours that there is a bank loan function!

content:
, 2015
												Hours Logged - 44Okay so I promised myself that'd write an honest review of this game, but only after logging a fair few number hours in order to sure what I was writing is accurate.The game is a vast improvement on the 2014, more polished, more complicated (Love stripping an engine to find a mystery fault), and a lot more room for potential.I've logged 44 hours for this game and I'm not even bored, in fact I'm actually finding myself getting more enthralled due to the auction system, and the refurb jobs I currently have in the parking garage.So in summary:Pros:-- The game will always keep you guessing, even after you have got all the add on's for the garage.- The auction is brilliant, nothing more satisfying than buying a wreck and doing it up.- The cars you work on well rendered and have actual real world issues.- The test track is worth its weight in gold.Cons:-- The game needs more depth in regards to cars available.- I've got an over abundance of XP points and nothing to spend them on.- More DLC as the Youngtimer pack introduced what seems to be a Fiat 500.- The garage itself needs to be open to change, maybe allowing us to move stuff around.So in conclusion, this game is good but needs a little more refinement to make it great.4 out of 5JB

content:
y 7, 2016
												TL;DR: All in all, a very enjoyable game for anyone, but especially for petrolheads. :-)I would recommend this game to any petrolhead/car fanatic out there. This is a very refreshing game, since it's the only one of it's kind that I know and it's very casual. For me, it's also a nice way to learn a bit more about the anatomy of cars  on top of the knowledge that I already have (and the fact that the game is translated to my native language also helps a lot, since I'm not too familiar with the English names for various parts). That's probably the downside, you'll need some basic car mechanics knowledge to get going. The tutorial isn't really all that explanatory, so if you're not familiar with the basics, it could take you quite some time to figure out what parts you actually need to replace and that can be frustrating.But, if you have some basic knowledge you should be fine. You can pretty much pull apart anything until there's just a skeleton standing. That's what makes the game so cool, there are no limits in what you can and cannot do. There are no set time limits for repairs, so if you feel like completely disecting a car, go ahead and do it!The XP points system keeps the game challenging. You need to unlock certain features to make your life as a mechanic easier like an OBD scanner to read the on board computer for any errors or better tools to be able to take out screws more quickly. The more XP you get, the more challenging jobs you can accept. And with more XP also come sweeter cars, since when you've built up a name for yourself, people with luxury cars also start finding their way to your garage.

content:
er 3, 2015
												Have to say that Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 is one of the few simulator games that actually does a good job, the graphics are great and runs smoothly even on high settings, have not encountered any bugs yet and is great fun to play.Pros:- Not encountered any bugs.- Active Developers.- Can customize Garage.- Can manage your own garage.- Great new test driving track.- Nice models and textures.- Nice background music while you tinker away with your cars.Cons:- Missing some key components from the cars such as fuel lines, brake lines, water hoses.- Small UI upgrade would be nice, selling/buying multiple parts can get a bit tedious.- Career mode could do with a couple more features such as business decisions, ranking and economy).Suggestions:- Could do with more cars, vans, pickups etc (Bikes?).- A bit more detail under the hood would be great wire, cables etc.- A bigger variety of engine types would be a huge bonus (petrol, diesel, hybrid).- The ability to upgrade your garage, as in starting from scratch and buying bigger property and equipment.- Being able to buy and add fuel lines, brake cables and water hoses to vehicles.- More customization options for vehicles such as:	- Size of alloy wheel	- Tyre sizes	- Full range of aftermarket exhaust systems/backboxes (varying shapes and sizes)	- Aftermarket air filters/ Induction kits.	- The ability to add turbo chargers and superchargers to cars.	- Adjustable ride height on suspension.	- Different paint types (metallic, matt, pastel, pearlescent).	- The ability to have engine parts chromed.	 - and finally different body styling modifications:		- Spoilers.		- Sideskirts.		- Hoods (carbon fibre, scoops, transparent etc)		- Window Tints.		- LED Lights.		- Variety of wing mirrors.		- Vented front fenders.- A couple of extra test tracks would be great also.Just some suggestions as food for thought though what you guys decide to do is obviously your choice along.

content:
25, 2015
												Good step up from 2014, some nice featers like 2 car lifts, better test track and an auction house where you can bid on cars you restore, even has a parking garage for I think 12 cars, I have six waiting to restore then sell on.  The missions are better, seems to make you work more.  Overall good fun.The only down side is the cars, well lack of cars.  There are 14 and they are not great, never even heard of them until now, think they all polish.  Guess Ford, Nissan and the rest did not want us gamers mucking around with there cars.  Also it seems to many items fit all rhe cars like only a single type of park plug, brake pad, brake calipar, clutch parts, even the drive axle is the same for all rear wheel drive cars.Another little bug bear of mine is hardly any cables or tubes, a few but even large tubes that would join the air filter to carbs are missing, this lets things like the air box, battery seem they are just floating in mid air being not joined to anything.  Was hoping this version of the game would have had more detail at all levels.  Its just odd that clips hold the air filter box on yet the exhaust parts just plop on and off with a mouse click, nothing to unbolt.  Just seems things have been left out as they did not have time to do them and you can see this with some items, as an example, there are three types of oil filters then on the other hand only one type of fuel filter and only one type of battery, the list goes on.Overall I am happy with this version for the cost, I just hope they spend less time in the pub and more time rendering 3d models to add to this game, even if they just changed the colour of similar items (they did with the oil filters) to make it seem there is a lot more to choose from would go a long way.

content:
24, 2015
												I liked the first car mechanic simulator (2014) but mostly gave up on it pretty early due to not being comfortable with both the interface and how the camera worked in-game. I'm happy to say this years version is just so much better. I've been playing for hours now (ignore the low hours played stat - Steam was down earlier so I played in offline mode) and it's a very entertaining game. Improvements such as the multiple bays, car auctions, upgrade paths - among many others - just make it a more complete game and I am very happy that I backed it on Kickstarter from the start.I'm only around 15 jobs in and the difficulty has been going up steadily in terms of type of repairs that I'm now being tasked with but - and this is a big but (ahem) - you're left to play the game at your own pace which is perfectly suited for this type of game. I'm having a blast playing this and can't wait to see the later parts of the game once I unlock them.For the price of £14.99 this game is a steal if you have any kind of interest at all in the basic workings of motor vehicles but I wouldn't expect to become a fully-fledged mechanic after putting a few hours into this. Although, having said that,  it's very likely your basic car knowledge of what parts go where will improve dramatically. I used to work in the automotive industry but in the administration side so this game appealed to me for that reason as well.As a comparison the nearest thing I can compare CM2015 to is the ancient Gearhead Garage that Snap-on bought out many, many years ago that was a fun, albeit simple, game repairing and doing up cars to flip at auction and make money. I'm hoping this game further in will vastly improve on that little gem from way back.Highly recommended. Well done to the developers.

content:
2015



YouTube™ Video: Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 - C - Axton's A to Z 

			Views: 64		

			Grab your Imperial Shifter Spanners, Left Handed Screwdrivers and attach your silencer to your rattle gun! It's time to get busy!		




YouTube™ Video: Now Playing - Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 

			Views: 71		

			What was the owner doing?!? An interesting job replacing 2 pistons and a turbocharger! Steam Store Link for Car Mechanic Simulator 2015: http://store.steampowered.com/app/320300/		

Farming Simulator, Bus Simulator, Construction Simulator, Grass Simulator, Goat SimulatorThere has been a lot of crappy simulator titles filling the steam store page over the last couple of years, but I was quite surprised last year with coming across Car Mechanic Simulator 2014.The Development Team at Play Way and Red Dot Games were really interested in a lot of the community feedback on the forums and wanted to implement a lot of their ideas by working on either DLC or an update to the game for the fansDue to funding requirements, they reached out to the community on kickstarter, where they did finally get funding to complete Car Mechanic Simulator 2015I was one of those backers and am very happy with how it has turned out!The production value is definately a large increase on the previous 2014 title witha lot of polish put into the game.Each car part is lovingly crafted with a beautiful attention to detail.Even without switching into the Part Examine Mode, you can tell which parts are severely warn by the amount of wear or rust tarnish on the part.In examine mode, most parts can be visually inspected without requiring the advanced tools needed, but in the case of Electrical Parts, you will need to purchase the diagnostic tool to be able to check or repair the parts.Later on in the game, you can also purchase a paint bake house and perform panel work as well as a testing line to assist in finding where that annoying little rattle is coming from.It starts you off in your Garage with the phone ringing to inform that a new job is available Selecting the phone gives you a list of availalble jobs, being able to accept or decline as you see fit.So Grab your Imperial Shifter Spanners, Left Handed Screwdrivers and attach your silencer to your rattle gun! It's time to get busy!Most of the initial starting jobs are simple tasks with parts lists or problem information attached. Like replacing filters, brake pads, Suspension Bushes, wheels and oil. Moving up to the more advanced areas like replacing Turbochargers, Pistons, Muffler Bearings, Crankshafts, Bottles of Boost and Timing Gear.The workshop is fitted with 2 Hoists and a central area, giving you the room to work on a couple of cars at the same time. This also allows access to other areas of the car as there is only so much you are able to do from the top of the engine bay.Repairing Cars are the main focus of making money, but you can also sell the old parts that were replaced for a little extra money. Once progressed far enough in the game, you have the ability to go to market and buy cars for your own overhauls and sell them at auction. A fantastic distraction on the side of increasingly difficult fault finding and part replacement.If you have ever been interested in cars, mechanics or even wonder how they all fit together this is a fantastic sim to get you into and learning all about the ins and outs of engines and suspension.And Maybe, Just Maybe, you might also realise that a few parts I mentioned don't really exist.

content:
er 27, 2015
												Good but a bit repetitive - Another relaxing game if you like to have something else to do while you watch TV or listen to the radio/podcasts in the background. Essentially, you're given a few different 3D jigsaw puzzles which have to take apart, find out which parts are broken (which appear corroded for some reason), replace/repair said parts, and put them back together again (the game shows you where they go). Optionally, you can perform diagnostic tests on vehicles to make finding broken parts easier, rather than find out for yourself by removing them from vehicles - But I think that also takes away the tiny ammount of challenge that this game has to offer.It also has XP and Levels to lengthen the content. Earn XP by completing repair jobs on vehicles, and unlock different cars, perks (more diagonstic tools, faster unbolting) and more complex jobs.There's not a lot to this game and it doesn't demand much of your attention once you've learned the basics, although it's nicely animated and does a good job at showing the very basics of car anatomy. You probably won't learn more than that from playing it, though. It's not an educational tool, if you're expecting it to be one.

												Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 is a great game. The game isn't super realistic but it is definitely fun. You learn to read the problem list and the parts required to fix them. There is a little bit of depth and after a few hours you will be able to take the entire car apart and put it back together without too much trouble. The real fun beings when you start to find the most efficient method of repairing a car and taking the extra steps to tune them early on in the game. I bought the base game and soon all of the DLCs. Totally worth it. They bring great variety to the game and getting the DeLorean was totally worth every penny when I finally got to work on one.Anyway, if you like a straight forward sim with a variety of parts and cars this is the best one out there as far as I can tell IMO. 4/5 Wrenches. :P

												This game is way more fun than it deserves to be. That is a good thing.Will you learn how to repair a real car? No. But it will give you a rough approximation of where certain parts are located in a car and a general idea of what they could look like. It's essentially a puzzle game. You are told the car has a noise in the engine, you need to find and repair the specific part. As you play you gain access to more testing tools so you can check the current durability of items without needing to fully disassemble the vehicle. But let's face it, eventually you will fully disassemble a vehicle for the fun of it, because you can.

												This is a huge improvement over Car Mechanic Simulator 2014.  I've owned it for only one week and have 32 hours on the game already (work full time, long commute, activities on the weekends).If you like to take things apart and build things, or like cars in general, you should check this game out.  It's not so true to life that you would be able to do major work on your own car with only this game as education, but you would learn which parts are which and generally where to find them.There are many other reviews that do this game more justice than mine, but I wanted to record my "yes" vote anyway.

content:
1, 2016
Product received for free
Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 ReviewCar Mechanic Simulator 2015 gives those unfamiliar with cars to familiarise themselves with the subject, but quickly runs out of fun.GameplayCar Mechanic Simulator is an immersive experience for the player, taking in account many important details to fixing cars.  Going into this game, I was expecting to be able to fix some sports cars or exotic vehicles, perhaps tuned ones.  Unfortunately, the game has a major issue with pacing.  I've fixed several cars already and still I've been limited to not only fictional, but very mundane and "nomal, uninteresting" cars.  I do have the maserati DLC but it took forever to unlock and from what I know, the Masterati's are the only true-to-life brand available to the player.  Despite my complaints towards the game's pacing, I have great respect for the amount of content and detail that the developer has been able to jam into this little game.  The player is able to take each vehicle out for a test drive, before and after mending them.  Each problematic or faulty component is conveniently highlighted in red and are usually very easy to spot.  Although CMS'15 lacks a rich tutorial, it makes up for it as the game is easy to pick up but difficult to master.  The goal of the player is not to simply complete each contract, but also to master the game and learn the car's components and their connection to performance.All in all, though CMS'15 isn't too much fun, it's definitely a rich learning experience and as a motorhead, I enjoyed learning more about the design of cars through the use of a car mechanic simulator.Pros+Immersive+Extraordinary detail+Enjoyable and forgiving learning curve+Very educational+Great visualsCons-Incredibly slow pacing-Fictional vehicles (understandable)-Tedious at timesRating: 7/10This review was submitted for Elite Giveaways, check us out for more reviews ranging from Indie games to AAA games.

content:
6, 2015
												This game DOES go on sale quite a bit, so definitely pick up while that's going on if you're thinking about getting it. For under $10, it's a decent buy. I definitely would not buy for $20 though. At the same time that this game improves upon a lot of the downfalls of CMS 2014, it still lacks a way to stop the mind-numbing process involved in getting to the good content of the game.  After playing for two hours, I'm still grinding through basic jobs in hopes of eventually getting to actually work on my own cars.I'd say the music has improved but still is an extremely repetitive playlist. They can't be more than 20 minutes long, if not less. **UPDATE** One new song was added since I wrote this. Probably a 25 minute playlist now. You're better off muting the game music and playing your own.If you haven't played CMS 2014, then it will be more likely that you enjoy this game since you won't notice how little it has really changed. It has definitely gotten better since then, but I think that maybe some more time developing should have been used.Basically, I really think that this game still needs work; but it looks like the developers are really looking for support from the community to do so gradually. That's fine. While it definitely is a finished product, some aspects of it just look very cheap. Don't get me wrong, I think this is a very good game. Not to mention it's pretty much the only mechanic sim out there right now. It's just that I feel like it still falls short of being a great game. It's almost feels like I bought an early access game without the label on it.I don't want to say this about the game because I know that the developers have worked very hard for this, but I really wouldn't be able to pass off pretending to fix virtual cars as a fun activity to anyone.  You're really better off watching informational videos on YouTube on how to perform the tasks you'd be doing in the game and maybe practicing on a real car than playing this game. Although it may feel like it has some educational value, you don't really need more than basic car knowledge to get these jobs done. Let's be real.I really don't agree with how little experience points you get from jobs that require you to diagnose several different systems and repair them. To even be able to access all of the new features of the game, you need to get a parking garage which costs 9000 XP. Over 20 jobs later, I'm only at 4000 XP. At least there's a bigger variety of problems to fix, unlike CMS 2014, but it's still just wayyyy too much. Why isn't the garage paid with money instead of experience anyway?All this aside, the game gets good support and still has updates and DLC coming, so there's hope all of this gets fixed eventually.

												This is a great game for those who are interested in cars (or just like to tinker with systems.) But let me state (and mind you I'm not a mechanic or a gearhead by any stretch of the imagination) that this game presents a simplistic and reductionist version of a car. If you don't know jack about cars you might walk away thinking you know how to fix a car. "It could be the tie rods connecting the front left steering knuckle" you'll say to your girlfriend as you look at her car when in reality your guess is just as good as anyother layman. Now the mechanics (ahem) aside, the car restoration bit is what keeps me in it. That sort of "Now what have we got here?" feeling you get when a new old beater comes into your ship. It's sort of exciting to be a kind of mechanical detective finding and fixing problems on an old car. And if you're unscrupulous, you can take older parts you have lying around and switch them for newer parts on a car sent into your shop for repair. Outfitted a whole Rino Piccolo with parts I looted from cars sent in for repair.Overall 10/10   Would definitely loot cars for their sweet, sweet gearbox components again.

content:
y 15
												I have a love-hate relationship with this game.I like taking cars apart and putting them back together. That by itself is quite addictive and has resulted in me spending many hours in this game. The graphics for the most part are also nice, if a bit dated.Unfortunately I dislike pretty much everything else about this game.First off, the tutorial and controls are awful. There are a lot of little details to playing the game that are not communicated to the player, and I had to resort to searching online to find out some very basic information on how to play.Next, once you get past the different exteriors, you'll find that there are only really four types of cars. I4 FWD, I4 RWD, old V8 RWD, and new V8 RWD. The parts are extremely generic and many of them are interchangeable between all of the cars.Buying replacement parts is quite annoying. You have to remember exactly which part you need, and many of the parts have very similar nondescript names (clip a , clip b, timing belt (V8), etc) so it's relatively easy to buy the wrong part and waste money. Until you spend your XP on the tablet upgrade, you have to run back and forth between the car and the desk PC to get parts.Game progression is tedious and annoying. You get 1 XP for taking a part off, putting it back on, or fixing it. This is true whether the part is an air filter clip or a gearbox. Fixing parts is annoying since you have an arbitrary chance to break it. Once a part is broken, regardless of its initial condition, it is now useless junk. Extremely annoying when said part is an expensive engine block in good condition that just needs a little polishing.Every 1000XP you earn an upgrade point. The game provides no guidance on what's actually useful. There are two upgrade categories: time saving tools and useless, disappointing cosmetic upgrades for the shop. Don't waste your points on the appearance upgrades, all they are is a handful of different colors for the indicated item. There are two critical shop upgrades you'll need to progress in the game: the paint shop and the top level of repair tools to repaint cars and fix car bodies respectively. Everything else is just a timesaver.Once you do get to the endgame of buying and restoring cars, you'll have to endure the supremely annoying car auction. This game managed to capture the annoyance of buying cars at an auction where there's always someone bidding you up so you end up paying 2 or 3 times (or more!) the starting bid for a car. After restoring a car, there's really not much you can do with it. You can put it in your garage and look at it, or take it to the underwhelming drag strip. All you can really do at the strip is endlessly race yourself. It doesn't help that the driving mechanics feel like an afterthought and the graphics on the drag strip are significantly worse than the rest of the game.This game has ridiculous loading times even on a fast PC with a SSD. I don't know what the devs did wrong, but it takes over a minute to load the shop and scene changes are equally slow.The DLC is the thing I hate most about this game. It appears that the devs removed some core features from the game to sell later as DLC. If you own all the DLC it would likely address the endgame and variety issues and add some much needed part swapping mechanics, but the fact that it is being sold as DLC and not included in the base game is unforgiveable. The base game is rough and unfinished and needs some TLC, but the devs are more interested in churning out more DLC packs. I get that they need money, but finish the base game first before tacking on DLC.Overall, while the core gameplay is addictive, when you take a step back and look at game as a whole, there's really nothing worthwhile here there other than that core sandbox.

content:
2015
												Usually when I see Simulator in the title of game I avoid the game like the plague!  More often than not, the classification of "Simulator" is abused and misused by developers hoping to cash in on a weak Genre with very few good games. I am very pleased to say there's actually a game in here! This does not play like an early access game. It feel more like a finished game they keep adding stuff to, and I personally love it. However would I title it a "Simulator"? That's a bit of a stretch. But overall, it's still a nice game. I have very few complaints about the game, mostly with some of the odd steps you must take to complete a job, like completly removing the exhaust manifold to remove the front exhaust pipe for example or your HAVE to remove the Starter from the top, not the bottom (on some cars). Also the total lack of gaskets in the game is perplexing, this is a simulator - where are the gaskets? But overall I would recommend this game to car lovers, mechanics, and simulator players. There's game to be had here!!Things I would like to see added before final release:Ability to fix body partsAir wrench upgrade option.GasketsOption on/off for auto mouse movement (game moves mouse at certain stages and get confusing)Customization items for car parts - UPDATE - Feature added to game but as a freaking pre-release DLC, thanks for showing your love for your supporters (sarcasm). It's a sad sad day when Alphas get Alpha DLCs. Pickups (there are no pickups in game) - UPDATE DLC ADDONTire options - UPDATE DLC ADDON UPDATE: 6/26/16Came back to check up on this title.. looks like they added a few of my wishes to the game.. but.. yep, as ♥♥♥♥ing DLC. Come on guys! ♥♥♥♥.

content:
2015
												I have played both of the car mechanic simulators, and I have to say, this one is better in every single way. And you can't ever complete this one, because jobs are unlimited and randomly generated. This game is very addictive, and it feels a lot like euro truck simulator 2 but with fixing cars instead of delivering cargo. This is not one of those crappy simulators you usually see on steam, this is amazing like euro truck simulator 2. Also, you can modify the colors of your workshop, buy attachments like a paint shop, a test area and a parking garage where you can store your car collection. You gain exp from working on cars, and with it, you unlock more cars with more problems to work on, more attachments to buy for your workshop, and you get upgrade points to upgrade your character, and to get tools to help you identify problems with cars. There's a lot more cars in this one than in 2014, and they are much more detailed with much more parts. This time you can work on the cooling system, open up the engine block and replace pistons or the crankshaft and the crankshaft bearings and everything. This game has insane amounts of detail, and the graphics and textures are mind blowing. The reflections are also really nice. The game also runs really smooth, and you don't even need the recommended graphics card if you want to run the game on Ultra graphics settings. I run it on Ultra very smoothly with my GTX 560 TI 2GB Phantom graphics card, so yeah. I honestly have never seen such gorgeous textures and reflections in a game before.  Well, Gta V has nice reflections, but still, this game is gorgeous too. In this game you can not only work on the parts of your car, but also on the panels, like doors, fenders, bumpers, lights, etc. Also, this game has tons of free DLC coming out, and they look like they will be amazing! The game's soundtrack is pretty cool too, even though I'm not really a fan of dubstep, I enjoy the game's dubstep soundtrack. It gets repetitive after a while though, because there's not a lot of songs in the game. I would like it a lot if they add more songs, and perhaps also a custom radio thing where you use your own music for the game's playlist. At the moment when I feel like using my own music, I turn off the game's soundtrack in the options menu, and run my playlist in the background, but I think it would be awesome if they added an in-game feature to use your own music, so you don't have to turn off music in the options each time you want to listen to something else. This game is also well worth the $20, and I highly recommend you buy it!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
2015
												Usually when I see Simulator in the title of game I avoid the game like the plague!  More often than not, the classification of "Simulator" is abused and misused by developers hoping to cash in on a weak Genre with very few good games. I am very pleased to say there's actually a game in here! This does not play like an early access game. It feel more like a finished game they keep adding stuff to, and I personally love it. However would I title it a "Simulator"? That's a bit of a stretch. But overall, it's still a nice game. I have very few complaints about the game, mostly with some of the odd steps you must take to complete a job, like completly removing the exhaust manifold to remove the front exhaust pipe for example or your HAVE to remove the Starter from the top, not the bottom (on some cars). Also the total lack of gaskets in the game is perplexing, this is a simulator - where are the gaskets? But overall I would recommend this game to car lovers, mechanics, and simulator players. There's game to be had here!!Things I would like to see added before final release:Ability to fix body partsAir wrench upgrade option.GasketsOption on/off for auto mouse movement (game moves mouse at certain stages and get confusing)Customization items for car parts - UPDATE - Feature added to game but as a freaking pre-release DLC, thanks for showing your love for your supporters (sarcasm). It's a sad sad day when Alphas get Alpha DLCs. Pickups (there are no pickups in game) - UPDATE DLC ADDONTire options - UPDATE DLC ADDON UPDATE: 6/26/16Came back to check up on this title.. looks like they added a few of my wishes to the game.. but.. yep, as ♥♥♥♥ing DLC. Come on guys! ♥♥♥♥.

ry 20, 2016
												As someone completely devoid of knowledge in mechanics, I can tell you that CMS2015 has taught me a LOT. It isn't as deep as it could be but it still can give you a basic notion if you play it and keep a tab open in your web browser to further study what you see in the game. I even managed to replace my car's air intake and air filter by myself =D .Basically you have to fix your customers' car, stripping down the car until you find what the problem is. You can use a number of tools to ascertain which parts are faulty or you can drive the car down a test track. You will have to purchase or attempt to fix the part by yourself, replace it and build it up again. You can also buy used vehicles and restore it, but it gets kinda pointless since there's nothing to do with it apart from photographing it and selling it. It's very casual and gets repetitive fast but still very fun to play. Recommended  for mechanics wannabes =P

, 2015
												Its a good game, but there could be some improvements made. Less detail in some areas, oil draining for example, the margin for where the drain pan is small, make that bigger. The way you disassemble and reassemble, you should be able to take off multiple parts at one time. A parts cupboard or something similar would be good to store repaired and used parts rather than have all parts mixed in together. A colour palette for the paint shop rather than a slider for hue etc It takes ages to collect XP. More toolbox upgrades. Timing and carb tune up options. Tyre options. A dyno tuner as well maybe. Trade cars with friends maybe, or race them. Theres so much more that can be done with this game. For now Im giving it 6 out of 10, only because there is so much room for improvment, I hope the creators keep working on this game to make it better.

content:
er 13, 2016
												Not as good as it should have been. The game is super grindy and has no real end-game. CMS14 had persistant customers and tuning that wasn't behind a paywall. My customers would wreck their cars or come back for additional work. In CMS15 all of the jobs are randomized. None of them make any sense. No one comes in for a set of front brakes, just one caliper, one set of pads, and a rear drum. Broken crankshaft, but everything else in the engine is fine. For some reason oil is simulated (like in CMS14), but coolant and gear oil are (still) not. The grind to unlock the parking lot to start buying auction cars is real, and you can't make real money with the auction cars until you have all 9 ranks of tool upgrades. At that point, the only thing to earn more money for is more spots to park cars that you can't tune or upgrade without shelling out more real $$ money.The models are a lot nicer than in CMS14, but the gameplay has gotten worse, and the DLC Simulator is real. Avoid this one and future titles.

content:
, 2016
												Some major points.I can say for certain the core gameplay is pretty decent. Informative for someone like me who only knows a few part names and has made few repairs on their car. There are a number of additions that i feel should defintely be included though. More fluids, electronics repair, part descriptions, better damage indicators rather than generic rust, and just listening to engine sounds to diagnose problems quicker - to name a few. This isnt a simulator, rather a collection of minigames based on the reality of auto mechanics.The progression and experience earning rate is dreadfully slow, though. It does feel like hours before i got to my first 1000 Xp and chose my first measly upgrade. Load times are pretty merciless. I really wish they would focus on smoothing it out rather than other features.Most importantly though; the DLC. Why on Earth would you release a "Gold"/complete version of this game that collects all of the downloadable content if you're gonna release another new dlc pack after, separately?? That's total lack of respect for your customers. I cant see why they wouldnt include it in an update, at least for those have the Gold version like me.This is an ethics issue that i cant forgive them for. I can praise the simple repair aspect of the game but i wouldnt recommend this on a account of poor professionalism from the developer.

content:
ry 8
												Would not recommend for the following reasons:- Totally lacking in challenge. You cannot assemble parts in the wrong order, you cannot return an incomplete car to a customer and money was never a constraint.- Very simplistic. Engine components are absent for simplicities sake. Once you've played the game a bit even the most complicated tasks take under 15 minutes. Broken components are identified by their heavy amount of rust (even on brand new vehicles).- After a few hours of gameplay the game becomes very repetitive.- Way too much part crossover. SUV, sports car, sedan all share 80%+ the same parts.I continued to play after I stopped enjoying it as I was hoping that buying cars in auction & restoring them to build a garage would be fun. I turned out to be even more tedious than the early game as EVERYTHING is damaged on every car. Why not just sell the body then if you have to strip everything every time anyways?The best way to fix this game would be to add some proper variety. Working on the "youngtimer" DLC that comes with the game shows what good DLC could do. The parts are entirely unique and vehicle assembly is different from every other car.The problem is the cost of DLC, it would be another $35 to add content that needs to already be in this game to recommend. I would suggest waiting until an "ultimate/complete edition" packages the game with all DLC for a reasonable price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 18, 2016
												As many others I got this game as part of the recent Humble Bundle for next to nothing so it's always going to be hard to complain.All in all this is a fun and mildly addicting game, but it does have numerous drawbacks.Pros:Good for the methodically minded (the game at its core is a puzzle game really)Noticeable progression.Everyone likes carsCan teach the basics of car engine layouts etc to the mechanical noviceCons:Can get very repetitive.The order that parts are attached/detached is basically nonsensical compared to real life.There's no simulation of wiring or piping etc in the engine bay other than ignition distributors in some models.Lots of features are locked behind grindwalls (you need <this much> xp to unlock the paint booth etc)The more interesting stuff (namely performance tuning) that adds a lot to the game is paid DLC as opposed to an addition to the core game.Most of the cons I can see were game design choices to allow a more casual market and I understand may have been necessary

												For the oldies among you who remember gearhead garage and buying some piece of... metal.. and then transforming it into a work of art, this is the new better version of that. Yep it has an auction room, garage and a test track (although I dont like the test track at all). You can paint your car any colour you want (doesnt seem to be any decals to apply though). On the whole a great game when you want to take a rusted heap of metal for a couple of thousand and turn it into a great profit. It can be a bit tediuos at first as you can only repair customer veichles. Once you get your parking though and a little capital... oh yeah. Nothing like a 100% castor rex standing in your garage, painted and ready to sell..I like this game very much and hope to see more content added in the future. I would especially like to see a better test track.

y 8
												I'm torn on this one - the game is somewhat addictive - until the repetitiveness starts - after a few dozen hours you have restored every car, know which faulty part causes which problem, have built your 'dream' car out of the available cars, have your repair skills maxed out and so on.I bought this game in a humble bundle with the youngtimer DLC (that ***** Maluch) included and bought the Trader pack and the performance DLC in a steam sale. In my opinion, the DLCs are a huge bad point of the game: some integral parts of the game must to be bought via DLC and even those are somehow incomplete. For example the performance DLC allows engine upgrades, but no suspension and brake upgrades. What's the point of the car upgrades anyway because there's only a dragstrip and nothing else.So you often get the feeling that parts of the game are missing. Another example: what is going on with car interiors? You strip a 1-star-condition car down to the naked shell, yet there's a pristine interior in it in which you can click around on named items, but no function.A last word on the car-brand-DLCs:DON'T! You pay about 6€/$ for a mere two additional cars and nothing else per DLC.Long story short: if you get the gold edition in a steam sale for less than 15€/$ or so, I'd recommend it, otherwise avoid it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
1, 2015
												I only put about five hours into it, so I'm sure there's plenty of stuff I haven't seen/done yet.First off, this is one of those odd European simulation games. You're a car mechanic. You fix cars.No jetpacks, no fire breathing dragons, no guns.At the start you're dropped into your garage. There's no tutorial. Occasionally when you look at a menu, or try something out there will be a brief tooltip about what that particular feature does. This can hamper your enjoyment. For example I spent a good 15 minutes trying to figure out how to order parts. I should have seen the obvious, that you use your computer to search for, then order parts. Makes perfect sense in retrospect.But, you say, how is the repair portion? You know, the actual meat of the game! At first, everything is deeply confusing. First, you look at the repair order. In the beginning it tells you what parts need to be replaced. You go over, select the proper view mode, and start clicking on parts. In one mode, parts can be inspected. In another mode you can disassemble parts. In another you reassemble. So, basically it goes, find the problem, remove bits until you can remove the problem part, replace and reassemble. Later more difficult jobs appear, that give you a general idea of the problem, and you need to search for the bad parts yourself. Eventually you wind up doing bodywork as well as other repairs. Also there is a point where you can buy, repair and resell cars, but I haven't gotten to that point yet. The layout of parts is somewhat simplified. There isn't any wiring that I've seen so far, and I haven't had an interior job yet. These things may happen later though. As you do more jobs, you gain experience. This allows you to have access to more tools, more in depth jobs, and different kinds of cars to work on.I'd say I'd recommend the game. It's oddly calming and soothing, while at the same time providing an interesting challenge. It does have a demo, so if you're interested, try it out!

content:
5, 2015
												The game in all is one of the few games that actually make me glad I am choosing to become a car mechanic in my future. This, although with a lot less of the frustration really working on a car can bring, is accurate, but only to an extent. As said by many people, it’s missing the human factor to it. From the “I can’t touch anything or I’ll have to clean grease off it” incident to the “I’ve lost the one screw and will have to replace the whole part” mistakes. It’s also missing the whole electrical aspect of cars; it would be cool if they could have cars that you would work on that showed you just what the working of a smart car is like.  I would hope that in future updates it will allow:-More car customization, such as different paint jobs (which can even be a part by itself where you have to paint each stencil/layer yourself)-Ability to work on the interior of the cars -Ability to go to car shows and drive the car around and get awards and money -As many car types as you can think of from all different car companies (Can give the ability of the player to load all or just some of the cars they want to work on) including different engine types -Create a customer system where people come in and have their cars fixed within a certain time span (have the phone for people who have bigger projects and have the schedule on computer) It's unrealistic that people would wait to have their car fixed while I'm out at auction and fixing my own cars or just goofing around-System so that you can sell cars to not just people at auction, but do trades as well-Allow players to expand the shop, adding more lifts, open floor areas, and have the ability to hire people in your own shop to help with buying items, fixing parts, testing and painting cars, even buying /selling cars, and even having them take care of a project by themselves -Different modes for players to choose from, such as casual (which is basically what the game is now), a career mode that would start with your business only getting a few costumers, would grow depending on the player’s judgment, and would have ways of advertising and seeing how well you are doing -Ability to add mods (which would help add new cars and different aspects while keeping the game itself simple and giving players the option to expand-Broken parts are not all rusted; parts can have breaks, malfunctions, be clogged but unnoticed until it is actually inspectedThe game as it stands is a good time consumer and definitely helped me distinguish that not every part is called “that round doohickey” or “that thing” due to that I have to look up every part individually by name in order to order a new one. It’s a great educational tool that is easy to work with and understand. What I find absolutely amazing is that even with my slow computer I can run this game with no problem with high quality and only minimal lag with ultra high quality with the only problem just being mouse movement is slowed. I like that it is realistic in the aspect that if you spend all your money on a car you won’t have enough to buy parts to get more money or fix the car and will eventually have to chop shop a car. What is nice is that the game is still being updated and actively worked on. It’s a game where sometimes I can’t stop until I’ve made enough money or until I’ve gotten down to only one customer but then I realize that I have parts to fix, then that I should sell some things, then that there is another customer. But wait, it’s a different car I haven’t worked on. Now I have to find the parts that need to be replaced because they are located everywhere or it has a V8 OHV engine and all the rods and rocker arms need to be taken out.  But then I’ve made the mistake of once again not going to bed when I wanted to. It feels like a Billy Mays commercial… “But wait! There’s more!”Overall, Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 is an amazing game. I would even be willing to pay for updates such as the ones I’ve listed because just one of those alone will bring hours of more fun, discovery, and things to learn about.

												Awesome game. ry 29, 2016
												The gameplay is addicting, even for a person like me who knows (or knew, I guess I should say) literally zero about how cars work. A true gearhead will see more lasting value to the overall product. As someone who enjoys deeper gameplay elements, however, I feel there's something lacking. You the player simply work on cars to make more money, which leads to easier and faster methods of working on cars, and that's about it. I would have really liked to see a career mode in which you eventually own and operate a living, breathing shop with budgets to manage, employees to hire/train/fire as appropriate, and perhaps eventually build a nation-wide chain of shops if your business acumen is up to the challenge.In other words, great core mechanic mechanic (so happy I got to say that) that has lots of room for expansion as an overal game concept. Also maybe throw in customer interactions, crappier computers, weak coffee, deadlines for getting work done... the list could go on.

content:
2015
												This review assumes you know Car Mechanic Simulator 2014 and it's game mechanics - either from playing it or watching lets plays etc.If you've played Car Mechanic Simulator 2014, this is a lot like that - a bit too much to my liking actually. It feels like what 2014 should have been, yet not a big enough step forward for a brand new game. I still recommend it because there aren't many games like this out there and it's got a reasonable pricetag for the value you're getting.This game is a bit more detailed than 2014, but shares all of it's good parts, so I'll just talk about things that I was a bit disappointed with:What I find is really lacking is a sense of progression. There are unlocks you get with experience but it feels a bit tacked on and not like a core game mechanic. I'd love to have either a story like in the similar Nintendo DS game "Touch Mechanic" (which is by the way a lot of fun) or a more extensive way of upgrading your tools and garage - i.e. starting in a small garage and buy better ones later on.What I think would be nice to have is a less strict assemble and disassemble order - allow me to make mistakes, for example get the order wrong in which I put together parts if I'm not careful. Let me interact with all the parts as I see fit - i.e. let me stop mounting a part mid-way and continue later if I want to - don't just completely remove it if I stop.The body-parts system is shallow - you take off and mount parts without so much as touching a screw. Similarly the painting system is just picking a color and pressing a button - I would have expected to spray the car myself.What I still hate since the first Car Mechanic Sim game is buying parts - it's a dumb waste of time to look up each part on a pseudo web-page - allow me to bulk order all parts that I found out need changing!That all said, if you like the concept of the game or the previous Car Mechanic Simulator, this is the game for you - there aren't many like it out there.For a future Car Mechanic Game I'd wish for these things:A physics system - no magically disappearing and reappearing parts - let me unmount them and physicalls move around the garage. It doesn't have to be as sloppy as in Surgeon Simulator, but something similar in concept would be fun.Also it would be great if one could unmount whole blocks of parts without taking it apart piece by piece.

												I supported this game on kickstarter and I am very glad that I did support it.Here is my first impression and live gameplay on ULTRA high settings:


YouTube™ Video: Car Mechanic Simulator 2015-Live gameplay #1-Ultra settings-First impression with commentary 

			Views: 1,004		

			Welcome back everybody, it's been a while I uploaded video here. Car Mechanic Simulator was just released and here is the first impression and gameplay on ULTRA settings.		

Ok well let's start quickly by saying if you played CMS2014 you will love this game, if you didn't play CMS2014 you will still love the game ;)I played lots and lots CMS2014 and couldn't wait for this game to come out.So what is the main difference between CMS2014 and CMS2015?Good quesion, but easy to answer.Everything is different ;)Lets start with graphics. Briliant, Absolutely superb graphics to the last detail. 5starNext, gameplay. Gameplay its similar to CMS2014 but improved a lot ( specially camera movements ) everything its a lot easier. 5starNext, parts. Car has A LOT MORE parts specially engine is absolutely design to the the last screw. Unlike in CMS2014 you can take whole engine apart, so you looking at more than 200+ parts per car. but I will try to take car apart and confirm this*. 5starThe garage and whole enviroment looks so real it will make you speechless. 5starYou can buy very cheap cars on auction and repair them put them together and sell them making lots of profit.And off course you can upgrade you garage tools and to get more cars in at once.Does game have any cons/something what needs improving? So far I haven't find anything bad ;) sorry my fault, I found 1 word in tutorial what supposed to be "by" and it was "my" so only this so farFinal verdict? 5 star game so very good price with absolute superb graphics and gameplay with lots and lots parts and you can use to learn bit about cars and engine ( kind of ) gives you idea what is where and roughly how to repair it :DI hope this is good enough to change your mind and you buy a game and enjoy it ;) Good luck and have fun

content:

												A great game. A huge upgrade from the 2014 CMS. Here are my pros and cons.Pros:- No storyline from what I can tell, unlike CMS 2014 where it was set up.- Classic muscle cars, my favorite.- Better camera than 2014.- Body modifications/jobs.- Basically a huge upgrade from 2014 CMS, I could list so many more things. Maybe take a look at the CMS 2014 trailers for a preview of the upgrades?Cons:- Uh, plastic rims don't rust???- When taking off a driveshaft on RWD vehicles (Bolt Reptilia, Hellcat, Magnum, etc) it is a little difficult to get a good angle, the best way to take off the drive shaft is to click the middle muffler and then unscrew the driveshaft.- No free roam as of now. You can get a parking garage and collect cars, but to be honest, whats the point of collecting cars if you can only drive them around an old factory test track? I would absolutely love to be able to drive to the Auction house/garage/test track myself. If the player doesn't have a car to drive there, they could just fast travel, what is in the game now.Overall the game is great, it's just the little tid-bits that make or break the game. I can see a lot of potential for more things to be added, such as free roam, the ability to put old engines in new ones, switch out a V4 for a V8, etc. A great simulator nonetheless, PlayWay is a great dev. If you're not nessecarily a car guy, and maybe don't know your way around a car, it might be a good idea to try out CMS 2014 first, maybe pick it up on a sale.Honestly CMS 2014 & 2015 are two of the few simulators that actually simulate, and don't run like sh*t.I'd also like to mention that the devs update the game rather than making the game a cash grab. They balanced the game, are planning to add more cars/features, and more.Definitely worth the $20.

YouTube™ Video: Car Mechanic Simulator 2015-Live gameplay #1-Ultra settings-First impression with commentary 

			Views: 1,004		

			Welcome back everybody, it's been a while I uploaded video here. Car Mechanic Simulator was just released and here is the first impression and gameplay on ULTRA settings.

												Very complete and real simulator! They should encourage kids to play this at school, learning so much. At the beggining is tricky and if you don't have at least some knowledge you will end up deasambling the whole car and assembling it again. As long as you know how an oil change is done and you are familiar on where some parts are located you should be fine. And if you get stuck in a job o get frustrated you can abort it without any penalties and then try different car jobs. After playing bread simulators, goat simulators, survivals of all kinds... I think this is the most and way far best simulator I ever played. 10/10... Of course if you are not a pretolhead or not interstead in mechanic or learning this game is not for you.+PROS:+you get jobs+you buy car parts+sometimes you need to examine the car and find out what is wrong with it (far more easy than it sounds)+remove/place parts one by one, screw by screw+get paid+buy tools and upgrades to improve your job+as more experience you make the more challenging and complex the game gets and more FUN+awesome electronic/EDM background music+no bugs found yet, exept once I removed a part and got it twice which is nice.+repair parts+sell parts+and more (yet for me to discover)-CONS-you can get stuck on a job, but you can quit it and recover-some parts are so small and difficult to find sometimes but thats part of being a mechanic simulator-needs patience-need to be intersted on cars or the science behind them (specific audience)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
29, 2015
												The visuals and gameplay mechanics are really good, once you get the hang of them, they feel very natural. At it's core the game is about finding faulty parts and replacing them with new parts. The challenge comes by not knowing which parts need replacing, and finding them using different techniques and tools you unlock along the way. There is also an auction system where you can buy cars, repair them, then keep them or sell them for a profit.One thing I really wish they had is some description of what each part does in the car. I have the basic understanding of how an engine works, but even the smallest blurb would have been helpful and a nice addition to the budding mechanic in all of us.Now for nitpicking, would it have killed them to put in a buy button to the work order? As of now you have remember the required part, switch to your tablet and find the part to buy. How about an indication of whether you already own the part? Instead you again have to remember the part, switch to your inventory and search it up. Sure, it's a simulator, that's part of the game, but it does get quite tedious and distracting when you have to search 20 different parts individually.Lastly sit down and be ready, unlocking everything is quite a grind, though personally I don't mind, I find it oddly meditative.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
1, 2016
												I wanted to learn more about cars in a fun way. This game does that.I like doing things myself, and learning how things work. I change my own oil and brakes, but looking at the car all the parts were just a mass of inscrutable metal shapes. After playing this game for some hours, I suddenly saw all the parts for what they are. Running Gear. Sway bar. Tie Rod. Tie Rod End. Strut. Coil Spring. There are individual parts, and they have names and purposes.ConsThere are very few interesting decisions in this game.  There's no strategy elements like managing prices or over/under charging, no honesty level, no sales or marketing or competing with other mechanics. The process of repairing cars never changes. There end game is buying cars from the auction, repairing, them then selling or keeping them. Load times are awful for what the game is. The upgrades are boring. The UI when selecting parts can be finicky.I feel like it was a real lost opportunity that the game doesn't offer information about each part. I know I can go hit Wikipedia, but it'd add so much to my experience if I could just right click the timing belt and learn it's function, maybe origin and evolution. What is the difference between a carburetor and fuel injection? Why did older cars have a middle muffler? This would add a lot of resource to the game.Pros If you're looking for car knowledge, this is 1000x more interesting than reading a website or book about cars.It doesn't turn you into a mechanic, but takes the mystery of automobiles and brings them into the realm of the knowable.Your fingernails aren't black for days after.

												Car Mechanic Simulator 2015. You can get rid of almost every part of your car, test your cars, sell them, even go to the Auction House and buy rusted, busted cars. This game may seem a bit expensive, but it's definitely worth the $19.99 you have to pay. I'd buy it if I were you.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
26, 2015
												I got last years game and decided to buy the 2015 version straight away. It's a good game!. Sometime a job will come along in the game and your be taking a lot of the car apart just to find that one faulty part. A basic knowlegde of cars is needed but you will learn fairly quickly about how to take the parts on and off and in what order.  Everything in the game is very decent or better, the sound. the graphics, the gameplay and so far i haven't come across any bugs. There's quite a few extra 'help' in the game like the OBD scanner or a test brake/suspension place in your garage but they cost one experience upgrade which is 1,000 XP in the game, It takes quiet a while to level up, so there's no way your get everything without some hours put in. My biggest problem with the game is the repairs list. You can only see what you need to replace on a list while near the car, once you go to the computer to buy new parts that list is gone. It can be very annoying traveling back and forth to the car to see what you need or you have forgotten. I do know once you unlock repair the items on a bench yourself, you won't need the list as much but i feel the repair list should always be available by pressing O, no matter where you are. Overall i'd give this game a 8/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
27, 2015
												CMS 2015 basically takes the 2014 version and improves it. They have different vehicles but more of them and somewhat more detail such as body panels, radiators and fans etc that sort of thing. I have enjoyed playing it though imo there doesn't seem to be much of a challenge financially as it's pretty much a continuous upward climb towards riches. At 9000 xp (7ish hrs for me) you unlock the abillity to buy cars in various conditions and fix them up which is fairly rewarding and has greater financial risk/reward if you don't manage your funds.All in all I wish the game was more detailed (ex. piston heads don't require removing bolts from underneath to remove, many bolted parts are simplified, no fasteners on body parts, only fluid you deal with is oil, so no coolant, trans, gas, wiper fluids etc all omitted, no hoses, no tuning, no interior parts, no glass repair etc. However it is still a fun game, and somewhat educational though simplified.TLDR; If you are interested in car mechanics you'll like this game, it isn't ultra detailed but it has enough to be fun and challenging at times. Do not expect 100% accuracy to real life.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
29, 2015
												This game surpasses the original by a large margin. There are a few annoyances, such as:1. Needing to make sure you put replacement parts in the exact spaces they should go. for example, rocker arms. There are 16 of them on a vehicle, if you need to replace 3 of them, you may need to remember exactly where the 3 brand new ones are supposed to go.2. Insane amount of XP required to buy the parking garage, so you can buy cars at auction to flip. 3. Getting some jobs, where you need to paint the the car, even though you still need one or two thousand XP in order to unlock the paint shop.4. A few very minor bugs which happen where it doesn't let you work on anything, because it doesn't think you are looking from the correct position on the car (like looking in the engine bay, to work on the engine).5. Dumbed down some of the dual parts. such as suspension arms, you buy one type of suspension arm, and it works on both the right, and left side of the vehicle, which should normally be impossible.The positive definitely outweigh the negative on this one though. You can take apart far more pieces to the cars than the original game, the parts website has been upgraded with some search filters, and a functioning search box, to find exactly what you're looking for, continuous game play, and you decide what jobs to work on, and when. If you want to work on random job, just go to the phone and pick one of the four options, or after you get your parking garage, you can buy a vehicle at an auction, fix it up, and sell it for a profit.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
29, 2015
												Being early in the release of the game and with dlc on the way, this game has impressed me and got me hooked, waiting for more...The detail of the cars is amazing, and while I thought it would be boring, I found myself hooked playing it for the last 4 days.  Troubleshooting and repairing vehicles is recreated in this game, however to a slightly limited scale. If I had to nit pick problems with their product here, it would be only that it is too basic. The idea that you canrebuild a car with a ratchet and socket is unrealistic, and I would like it if they added usable hand and power tools in the future. First and foremost in my mind should be a torque wrench, where you have to look up torque specs and sequence (could be done using the computer?) and having to set the torque value on the wrench and torque in sequence. welders and paint guns could also be neat to use when doing body work or painting. I think automatic transmissions would also be a must add.Im sure some of these features will come in time, but as of right now, im fairly pleased with the game. Id recommend it to any car guy or gear head in an instant.

content:

												This is one of those zen type games.  It draws you in and you just kind of lose yourself in playing around with the cars, removing parts, seeing what connects to what and how and then fixing everything and putting it all back together again.  It's very fun but also very relaxing.  It's kind of like when you're a little kid and want to take apart your toys or the toaster or a radio but here you don't have to worry about mom or dad smacking you when you can't put it back together again.  Not sure how realistic the game is in terms of learning how cars actually work but it's really fun and you can easily lose an hour playing it before you realize.  Definitely worthwhile.

First and foremost in my mind should be a torque wrench, where you have to look up torque specs and sequence (could be done using the computer?) and having to set the torque value on the wrench and torque in sequence. welders and paint guns could also be neat to use when doing body work or painting. I think automatic transmissions would also be a must add.Im sure some of these features will come in time, but as of right now, im fairly pleased with the game. Id recommend it to any car guy or gear head in an instant.

content:
29, 2015
												This game surpasses the original by a large margin. There are a few annoyances, such as:1. Needing to make sure you put replacement parts in the exact spaces they should go. for example, rocker arms. There are 16 of them on a vehicle, if you need to replace 3 of them, you may need to remember exactly where the 3 brand new ones are supposed to go.2. Insane amount of XP required to buy the parking garage, so you can buy cars at auction to flip. 3. Getting some jobs, where you need to paint the the car, even though you still need one or two thousand XP in order to unlock the paint shop.4. A few very minor bugs which happen where it doesn't let you work on anything, because it doesn't think you are looking from the correct position on the car (like looking in the engine bay, to work on the engine).5. Dumbed down some of the dual parts. such as suspension arms, you buy one type of suspension arm, and it works on both the right, and left side of the vehicle, which should normally be impossible.The positive definitely outweigh the negative on this one though. You can take apart far more pieces to the cars than the original game, the parts website has been upgraded with some search filters, and a functioning search box, to find exactly what you're looking for, continuous game play, and you decide what jobs to work on, and when. If you want to work on random job, just go to the phone and pick one of the four options, or after you get your parking garage, you can buy a vehicle at an auction, fix it up, and sell it for a profit.

content:

												Incredibly fun game providing a good load of knowledge about car mechanics - instant fav!I remember playing Street Rod on C64 a long time ago where I could tinker around the car in a very limited way and I loved it. I'm interested in classic cars (now we have the second classic in my family) and that involves lots of real life mechanical repairs and/or adjustments which made me really curious about how to deal with certain mechanical problems. I'm extremely happy to have this game and getting a better overall view of the whole picture through it. Now it' much easier for me to approach towards any upcoming problmes of my classic :)CMS 2015 is literally an interactive learning material combined with game elements. Great thing, don't miss it!Update: I got my first complete restoration finished: a "Bolt Reptilia" (which is a Corvette literally) - it was a frenetic experience. Taking it apart bit by bit, remove every single part possible and rebuild it to a shiny 100% condition is just like a pilgrimage. The chrome is fantasic under the hood! And also I guess this is how far the game can go really but repeating this over and over again is a joy.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
2015
												Car Mechanic Simulator 2015 is a solid improvement over 2014.  The amount of destructable parts you have is much better than before.  I like that you can now restore cars and work on their bodywork too.  The possibility of DLC should keep the game fresh with new challenges and vehicles unlike 2014 where once you have taken apart a v6 that was really it, game mastered time to move on.  I would recommend this game to people who are curious to see how cars fit together (all be it in a very simplified fashion).   However there are some drawbacks which I hope they iron out soon.1.  The music is annoying and repetitive, please add more stations and the ability to play my mp3s.2.  Colouring things rusty to indicate their condition really gives the game away.  I rarely need to use diagnostic equipement or test drives to isolate the problem.  Also, please stop giving me a list of things I need to replace, this compounds the issue. The whole point of the game to test my diagnostic skills and therefore the xp I get at the end of each job.3.   Using xp to unlock the ad-ons to your workshop like parking, paint booth and test path is stupid.  These should only be based on cash.  The whole xp to unlock thing puts the new car restoration part of game out of reach until the very end (9000xp = 100+ jobs) as you need to unlock the garage parking in order to visit the auctions.  I want to be able to buy a car and work on it slowely as money, skill and ad-ons allow.4.  Turning down jobs/doing a poor doesn't have consequences (except some xp)?!? are you kidding me? Customer rep needs to play a greater part.  As I recall there were repeat customers in CM2014 if my memory serves me correctly.5.  Tutorial needs to be bigger.  This is the part of the game where you give me a list of things that are wrong.  Also, put it outside the campaign.  If people are still struggling to to find things in the campaign perhaps introduce Workshop manuals that can be bought via the PC or Tablet???Well thats enough of the negatives, all in all I still enjoy the game and for only $20 I really think you cant go wrong.  It is different and thats why I like it.  I think the community and the developers will inmprove this game as times goes on.  Get on it.

												loved cms 2014 love cms 2015 keep up the good work, that being said, upgrades would be nice not just a add turbo option but actual upgrades some will take work to implement but some such as the double carby manifold setup should be really easy for the ohv v8 as it bolts on the same way as the single carby version using very little engine bay room evident with some of the old cars huge engine bay with a engine that leaves alot of room to fill, things like bigger high performance fuel pumps and air filters, different spring stats eg: stiff sport suspension or standard, also as in the picture above new modern engine in old cars would be great aswell as a bigger test track tuning that varies depending on parts installed, different option between modern and old car diffs eg: open diff, limited slip, and locked diff, even some different cosmetic changes like different headlight tail light options ect, adding variety like this would extend the already long playability by a heap being able to build multiple versions of the same car differently for noticable handling and performance differences a more in depth test track like at the ford factory would be nice a offroad section wet areas high speed turns ect, as for the driving controller support for the steering would be awsome along with manual gearbox option and handbrake would add a little more "screw around with your creations options" 9.5\10 will score a 10\10 once there a few more changes of which going by the screenshots you already have on your to-do-list once again great work and dont forget to think outside the box itl keep this game addictive and fresh for a long time to come

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
26, 2015
												I know nothing about cars other than my general knowledge of mechanical engineering. Cars were never an interest to me, and if something is wrong with my car, I always take it to someone to fix- never would I do it myself. Not even an oil change.That introduction aside, I LOVE this game. Even without that real-world interest level, this game is polished, sharp, and always has you eyeing goals in the future without holding your hand.  How rewarding it was when I was first repairing some more difficult issues, and without knowing where some parts were located, stripped down the entire engine of a car looking for those parts only to have to reassemble the whole thing- and get it right! It really is a great balance between simulating the work of a mechanic and gamifying it so that it's not quite so world-dreary and labor intensive.I am quickly banking cash and gaining experience with excitement, as soon in game I'll be able to buy a beat-up car at auction and fix it up to resell for huge profit as a side project in my garage.If you don't know cars, but enjoy simulations, progress, and have a bit of a mechanical-puzzle oriented mind, this is a very, very well done game and I highly recommend it. I may not be a mechanic after this, but at least my eyes won't cross in ignorance when someone says "catalytic converter" to me at the garage.Side note: I love the music in this game too. A great mix for working away at the cars in game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
26, 2015
												This game is fun and a good tool for locating and replacing parts of a car.  I have some experience in auto repair and other misc. hardware as I'm a maintenance mechanic for the USPS.  Since I'm no expert in repairing cars and I like to learn, I enjoy this game and I've learned quite a bit from the repair jobs I've done so far.At the time of this review I'm only a few hours into it but already I notice some things I would like to see added for extra realism.  For example, hoses (air, radiator and others) battery cables and other major wires, various fluids like washer, brake, transmission etc. and gaskets in the engine would be a nice touch. Something else that would help with the immersion would be to have different size wrenches and sockets with ratchets to use on different size bolts and nuts. I think it's important to have a lot of different parts for the different cars as most cars take different parts in real life; at least for the larger more important parts.  That would be nice to have to look up the make/model in the computer to get the right part. :)  Honestly I don't think it wouldn't be that hard to add that if only they added part numbers to the car part inventory.  Finally I would like to see options of stock, upgraded and high performance parts so you can upgrade the cars you buy.  Overall though the game has potential to take many hours of fun and learning.  Recommended.
